author: thezim
body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

`Measure-Object` currently does not have a builtin alias. Suggest that `mo` be added to the built aliases. I did not see any native binary conflicts across Linux (Ubuntu 20.04), Windows, or MacOS (Big Sur).

The following is a bit laborious especially if you run the command first and then decide you wanted the count.

```powershell
(gci -r -file).Count
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Add `mo` as an alias for `Measure-Object`.

```powershell
gci -r- file | mo
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Aliases, with rare exceptions, create more problems (conflicts) in general than useful. It is not recommended to use them in scripts. Users can still create them locally for the convenience of working in an interactive session, but this is a _personal_ preference and this could be placed in user profile..

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body:
None of the *-Objects have two letter aliases, by default. The object cmdlets do have aliases that are the same as the verb, so 

```powershell
gci -r- file | measure
```
If, while entering this line, you just type the M and E (of measure) then tab, tab completion completes the command correctly.

And as always - you can edit $Profile and add personal aliases.

comments.author: thezim
comments.body: I don't know how I over looked `measure`. On MacOS I have a 7 match on `me` but `mea` get me there.

title: Add alias for Measure-Object
